title.en: UTOPIA: The Last World War/Tama-chan the Angel

description.en:
A super fantastic book that became Fujiko Fujio's starting point

Fujiko Fujio's first and last newly illustrated book published by Tsuru Shobo in 1953. Drawn under the name Fujio Ashizuka, he moved from Toyama to Tokyo and brought it to several publishers, but it was not accepted, and after being introduced by Osamu Tezuka, the company decided to make it into a book. However, because the cover was written by Noboru Oshiro and was published in conjunction with other manga artists' works, the two subsequent reprints had Fujiko draw a new cover and the coupling work was removed, leaving the book as original. It wasn't. This time, we have achieved a complete reprint that faithfully reproduces the text in two colors based on the original that Leiji Matsumoto had preserved.
Earth was frozen by the ice bomb used by the S Federation during World War III. What the boy, who was confined in a shelter and revived 100 years later, sees is an Earth that has recovered from the damage caused by the ice bomb and has been rebuilt as a utopia with advanced scientific civilization. A masterpiece of apocalyptic science fiction that is still relevant today.

The first book and only newly illustrated work "UTOPIA: The Last World War" (1953) is finally available with two-color pages fully reproduced!
And a must-have for fans, which combines all 26 works of the phantom first serial and manga artist's debut work "Tenshi no Tama-chan" (1951), whose total number was unknown for a long time, for the first time. Super commemorative volume!
Commentary/Fujiko Fujio A.

biography.en:
藤子・F・不二雄
Fujiko F. Fujio
==
Fujiko Fujio (藤子 不二雄) was a pen name of a manga writing duo formed by two Japanese manga artists. Their real names are Hiroshi Fujimoto (藤本 弘, Fujimoto Hiroshi, 1933–1996) and Motoo Abiko (安孫子 素雄, Abiko Motoo, 1934-2022). They formed their partnership in 1951, and used the Fujiko Fujio name from 1954 until dissolution of the partnership in 1987.

From the outset they adopted a collaborative style where both worked simultaneously on the story and artwork, but as they diverged creatively they started releasing individual works under different names, Abiko as [Fujiko Fujio Ⓐ](https://mangadex.org/author/b755f10f-ad3d-4b22-ae7a-214025d70e72/fujiko-fujio-a) (藤子不二雄Ⓐ, Fujiko Fujio Ē, credited as Fujiko A. Fujio outside Japan), and Fujimoto as Fujiko F. Fujio (藤子・F・不二雄, Fujiko Efu Fujio). Throughout their career they won many individual and collaborative awards, and are best known for creating the popular and long-running series Doraemon, the main character of which is officially recognized as a cultural icon of modern Japan. Some influences of most of their projects are the works of acclaimed manga artist [Osamu Tezuka](https://mangadex.org/author/21575d70-b954-4e3a-80df-00192f413a83) and many US cartoons and comic books—including the works of Hanna-Barbera.
